article:
{{Infobox musical artist
| name = Kati Ilona AgÃ³cs image = caption = Kati Ilona AgÃ³cs (photo by: Samantha
| West) background = non_performing_personnel occupation = Composer genre =
| Contemporary classical origin = Windsor, Ontario, Canada birth_date =
}}

'Kati Ilona AgÃ³cs' (born January 20, 1975) is a composer of contemporary
classical music and faculty member at the New England Conservatory of Music in
Boston, Massachusetts. AgÃ³cs was raised on a small farm in Southwestern Ontario
by Hungarian and American parents. Her father left Hungary after the 1956
uprising against the Stalinist government and traveled to Italy and the United
States before finally settling in Canada. At the age of sixteen AgÃ³cs left home
to represent the province of Ontario at Lester B. Pearson College of the Pacific
(one of the United World Colleges), where she played guitar and sang in a Sonic
Youth-inspired rock band whose members included the art curator Massimiliano Gioni. [http://nymag.com/arts/art/features/gioni-new-museum-2011-
6/ New York Magazine] She then accepted a full scholarship to Sarah
Lawrence College based on a visual art portfolio, changing her focus to music in
her junior year. She attended the Juilliard School, where her principal
composition teacher was Milton Babbitt, from 1998 through 2005, earning masters
and doctoral degrees in music composition. She was a composition fellow at the
Aspen Music Festival and School and the Tanglewood Music Center, where she held
the ASCAP Leonard Bernstein Composer Fellowship in 2007. [http://www.ascap.-
com/eventsawards/awards/foundation/scholarships/bernstein_tanglewood.aspx/ ASCAP
awards]

Kati AgÃ³cs is a 2013 Composition Fellow of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial
Foundation. [http://www.gf.org/fellows/current/ John Simon Guggenheim
Memorial Foundation] She has also received an inaugural Brother Thomas
Fellowship from The Boston Foundation, [http://thephoenix.com/boston/news/91631-brother-thomas-
fellows/ 2009 Boston Phoenix Announcement of Inaugural Brother Thomas
Fellows] a Charles Ives Fellowship from the American Academy of Arts and
Letters, [http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/music/story/2008/03/05/agocs-win.html
2008 CBC News Announcement of Charles Ives Fellowship] and a composition
fellowship from the New York Foundation for the Arts, [http://www.nyfa.org/
2006 New York Foundation for the Arts] among many other composition
awards. She began her teaching career at Memorial University of Newfoundlandâs
School of Music (2006â2008), and has been a member of the composition faculty of
the New England Conservatory in Boston since 2008. She maintains a permanent
work studio in Flatrock, Newfoundland, and is an Associate Composer of the
Canadian Music Centreâs Atlantic Region. [http://www.cmcatlantichub.com/newfoundland/kati-
agocs/ Canadian Music Centre Atlantic Hub]

Kati AgÃ³cs is a popular new-music composer. [http://www.silive.com/entertai-
nment/music/index.ssf/2011/02/for_island_music_lovers_its_do.html/ Staten Island
Live] Orchestras and ensembles that have commissioned and played her
compositions include Eighth Blackbird, the Boston Symphony Chamber Players, the
Toronto Symphony Orchestra, the American Composers Orchestra, the National Arts
Centre Orchestra, Metropolis Ensemble, the CBC Radio Orchestra, the Minnesota
Orchestra, and Boston Modern Orchestra Project, which has performed and recorded
several of her works. [http://www.bmop.org/explore-bmop/musicians/kati-
ag%C3%B3cs Boston Modern Orchestra Project] Her music was an Audience
Choice winner at the SONiC (Sounds of a New Century) Festival in New York in
2011, and was archived at WQXR Radio. [http://www.wqxr.org/#!/articles/q2-music/2011/oct/19/resound-first-
installment/ WXQR ] She served as Composer in Residence for the National
Youth Orchestra of Canada during their Fiftieth Anniversary season in 2010. [http://www.hungarianpresence.ca/Culture/Music/kati-agocs-
219.cfm The Hungarian Presence in Canada] In 2007 she was one of ten
Canadian composers selected by CBC Radio to write a Prelude and Fugue for solo
piano in honor of the 75th anniversary of Glenn
Gould. [http://www.musiccentre.ca/node/40831/ 2008 CBC/Canadian Music Centre
Announcement of Glenn Gould Tribute CD: "So you want to write a fugue?"]

Kati AgÃ³csâs music is
lyrical, [http://www.sequenza21.com/cdreviews/category/innova/ Sequenza
21] emotionally direct, and dramatic, with clear overall
architectures. [http://metropolisensemble.org/concerts/2011/dash/kagocs.php
Metropolis Ensemble] One hears a natural affinity with vocal impulses, [http://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/17/arts/critic-s-notebook-works-
for-four-instruments-but-not-always-four-at-once.html 2004 New York Times review
of Antares concert (including the quartet Imagination of Their Hearts)]
fluid melodic lines, [http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2009/01/20/bo-
ston_modern_revels_in_conservatory_connection/ 2009 Boston Globe review of
Boston Modern Orchestra Project with Kati AgÃ³cs and Lisa Bielawa as soprano
soloists (performing By the Streams of Babylon)] and frequent cross-
pollination with literature from different cultures. Vessel (2011), a macaronic
motet for voices and chamber ensemble, presents three texts sounding in English,
Latin, and Hebrew simultaneously. [https://www.newmusicusa.org/musician-stories/kati-agocs-
composing-vessel/ New Music USA] Crystallography (2012) is a setting of
poetry by the Canadian poet Christian
BÃ¶k. [http://www.musiccentre.ca/node/67397 Canadian Music Centre]
AgÃ³cs dialogues with earlier composers, including a homage to GyÃ¶rgy Ligeti as
the second movement of her quintet Immutable Dreams, and tends toward harmonic
and textural richness and a wide expressive range. [http://www.cleveland.co-
m/musicdance/index.ssf/2009/03/eighth_blackbird_soars_in_mode.html 2009
Cleveland Plain Dealer review of Eighth Blackbird concert (including the quintet
âImmutable Dreamsâ)] She employs Serialist techniques to re-imagine a Bach
chorale in Versprechen (2004). [http://www.musicaltoronto.org/2012/11/24/daily-album-review-9-
vernon-regehr-bows-to-canadian-voices-to-solo-cello-repertoire/ Musical
Toronto] Her works often reflect specific geographical and cultural
settings, and the music associated with them. Shenanigan re-contextualizes a
Reel from Atlantic Canada within the modern orchestra, interlacing the reel tune
with her own material to create a hybrid symphonic work. [http://www.thesta-
r.com/entertainment/music/2012/09/27/bright_colours_dull_pianist_in_toronto_sym-
phony_evening.html/ 2012 Toronto Star review of Toronto Symphony Orchestra
concert (including the orchestral work Shenanigan)] Elysium, a work for
chamber orchestra and recorded audio tape commissioned by the National Arts
Center Orchestra for the 2010 Winter Olympics, reflects the distinct cultural
and physical environment of Newfoundland by interweaving original music with
field recordings of elderly natives of the island describing shipwrecks along
the coast. [http://necmusic.edu/ag%C3%B3cs-olympics/ New England
Conservatory: AgÃ³cs at Olympics] Saint Elizabeth Bells features the
Hungarian cimbalom in its scoring. AgÃ³cs performs her own works as a soprano so-
loist [http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2009/01/20/boston_modern_rev-
els_in_conservatory_connection/ 2009 Boston Globe review of Boston Modern
Orchestra Project with Kati AgÃ³cs and Lisa Bielawa as soprano soloists
(performing By the Streams of Babylon)] and collaborates with
instrumentalists to develop distinct techniques and musical colors. One of many
such collaborations is her work with Bridget Kibbey to create a bluegrass piece
for harp as part of the suite Every Lover is a Warrior. [http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/opera-classical/8443/bridget-
kibbey 2007 Time Out New York Review of the CD Love is Come Again by Bridget
Kibbey (including the work for solo harp Every Lover is a Warrior)]

AgÃ³cs has written on American music for Tempo [http://journals.cambridge.or-
g/action/displayIssue?jid=TEM&volumeId=62&issueId=246&iid=2360072 Tempo
(journal), Volume 62, Issue 246, October 2008] and also created a critical
edition of the Symphony in A Major by Leopold Damrosch, father of Walter
Damrosch, the founder of the Juilliard School, for A-R Editionsâs Recent
Researches in American Music Series. [http://openlibrary.org/b/OL8252543M//-
Symphony_in_A_Major_(Recent_Researches_in_American_Music)/ A-R Editions Recent
Researches in American Music, A-54] In 2005-2006 she lived in Budapest on
a Fulbright Fellowship and wrote a candid inside glimpse of the new-music scene
in Hungary for The Musical Times. [http://www.questia.com/library/1P3-1136549771/the-mechanics-of-
culture-new-music-in-hungary-since/The Musical Times, Volume 147, Autumn
2006] She had previously organized an exchange program between Juilliard
and the Liszt Academy. Juilliard Journal, October 2005, Raymond J. Lustig,
"Twin Concerts Foster a New York-Budapest Exchange of New Music" As a
result of these activities, the progressive Vienna-based Hungarian publication
BÃ©csi NaplÃ³ credited her with raising the visibility of Hungarian composers
abroad. [BÃ©csi NaplÃ³, "Hungarian Music Week in New York", MarchâApril
2007]
